title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: On each elbow ye have the purple Lammermuir,where a hundred hirsels graze; and to the east, the mighty ocean, wi'the ships sailing upon it, where, wi' their white sails spread to thesun, they look from the distance just like sea-birds poising themselveson their out-stretched wings owre the deep.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 9
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: I think I might almost have said the last: somewhere, indeed, in theuttermost glens of the Lammermuir or among the south-western hills theremay yet linger a decrepit representative of this bygone good fellowship;but as far as actual experience goes, I have only met one man in my lifewho might fitly be quoted in the same breath with AndrewFairservice,--though without his vices.

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The exported Scotswoman, Mrs.Bickerton by name, ate heartily of one or two seasoned dishes, drank somesound old ale, and a glass of stiff negus; while she gave Jeanie ahistory of her gout, admiring how it was possible that she, whose fathersand mothers for many generations had been farmers in Lammermuir, couldhave come by a disorder so totally unknown to them.

title: Redgauntlet: A Tale Of The Eighteenth Century
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I would have eschewed her,sir--I would, on my soul; for I was as innocent a lad as ever came fromLammermuir; but there was no possibility of escape, retreat, or flight,unless I could have got a pair of wings, or made use of a ladder sevenstories high, to scale the window of my attic.

title: Nineteenth century letters,

snippet: It is a piece of Tragedy, even to the muttering Thunder, like the Lammermuir, which does not look very small beside Peter Bell and Co.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Unlike the beautiful pastoral hills which form the ranges of Cheviot and Lammermuir, nothing can be more bleak, cold, and miserable, than this barren and uncultivated waste, presenting as it does, a desolate contrast to the Lothians I passed through but an hour ago ; a district over which the eye delights to range, where a surface of thousands of acres is loaded with ripe grain ready for the sickle, except where the yellow tint is relieved by the rich green of luxuriant turnip crops, or thriving plantations.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: The Cheviots are much lonelier than the Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: I mentioned that the Lammermuir was celebrated for its honey, and the Cheviots are not inferior in reputation.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: But we will say, that whether in the pastoral hills of Cheviot or Lammermuir, or on the classic banks of Tweed, " by day or night, or any light," the traveller may pass safely ; and over the whole district which " law-contemning" prickers rode, none will assail his person or effects.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: He, the liorlus siccus man, is obliged to be back at Falkirk in two days — and the bassoon-player has given him the pleasant intelligence that from the extent of the Lammermuir, two weeks may probably be con-

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: He, " good, easy man," was no assistance ; for although  he might have been first bassoon upon the Peninsula, he plays but second fiddle on the Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Wei'e his house more comfortable, the Highland  herdsman would have little time to enjoy it ; for a person who has not rambled through the Lammermuir and Cheviots, can little imagine the severe and never-ending business of a pastoral life in Highland regions like these.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Without one particle of bad luck, the Lammermuir will do the same for any gentleman, who has no objection to be boxed up with a fellow traveller for the night.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: They laid her beside him whom she loved in life — and the flower of Lammermuir reposes close to as brave a soldier, as ever pressed Highland  brogue upon a battle-field.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: He volunteered the first turn-out ; and ere a twelvemonth had elapsed, he who had been herding sheep upon the Lammermuir, had won a corporal' s stripes upon the red field of Albuera.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Donald was three years younger — and was admitted by universal consent, to be the finest lad within the wide scope of the Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: In the upper Lammermuir, the houses are in some places four miles apart — the connecting road a pathway, or a mere beaten track, undefined  by fence or hedge.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: But, at these sad seasons, on the Lammermuir the proprietors of cattle have severe visitations.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: I would freely undertake to walk twenty miles of sound heather, rather than five of the nondescript character of the Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: The Waltonian alternative was only left me — patience, to wit — so I unjointed my rod, wound my flies around my hat, and then sat down to muse upon the vanity of an angler's hopes and expectations,  beside as bright a run of water as flows through the Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: On a former visit to the Lammermuir, I went a mile up the river one evening to the valley where the Dy joins the Whitadder,  and in two pools, and within a few hundred yards of the junction of the streams, killed ten pounds' weight of healthy trouts — I name the

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: As the Cheviots are celebrated for the flavour of its mutton, the Lammermuir is famed for that of its honey.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: At nine next morning I started for the upper district of the Lammermuir — and at ten, my Phaeton, who drove the gig, pulled up at a lone caravanserai, occasionally resorted to by anglers, gentlemen who are called geologists — from carrying leather bags and hammers — and persons in the botanical line, generally supplied  with spectacles, I suppose expecting by mechanical assistance to find strange weeds, as Diogenes looked for an honest man by candlfe- aight.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: I retired for supper to mine own great chamber, to decide afterwards if I could, whether the vulpine fallacies of the Cheviots, or the adder heresies  of Lammermuir, were more unconquerable.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: The adder which seems peculiar to the Lammermuir, far exceeds in size any I had met with in the Highlands, and but for the unity in description  which all I spoke with preserved, I would have fancied that the venomous, little, dirty, ash-coloured reptile, scarcely ranging above a finger's length or two, had been confounded by the herds with the harmless whipsnake I had so often found in English forests, and frequently  in the Argyleshire muirs.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: While putting my rod together,  I fell into conversation with a herd who was skinning a dead sheep, and was informed by him, that the animal had been killed by an adder-bite ; and that the Lammermuir was as much afflicted with these reptiles, as the Cheviots had formerly been by foxes.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: But justice for Lammermuir obliges me to say that my chamber is clean and comfortable.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Lammermuir — as his Grace of Wellington would happily express it — is not Tipperary — and here you will not get a man shot for love or money ; and even an attempt at assassination would set the district in an uproar.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: and holds a central course through the most picturesque valleys of the Lammermuir, after having received a pretty tributary called the Dy, a mile above Elmford.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: The outline of the Lammermuir is wild, but beautfully pastoral.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: We took a by-road that branched towards the Lammermuir, and passed the field where the accident had happened.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: It rolled away, however, towards the left ; and, as it appeared,  its fury had been reserved for and discharged upon, the hills of Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: My visit to Lammermuir was to be unfortunately mai'ked nigro lapide, and indeed, will ever be one of painful recollection.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:

snippet: ral beauty and romantic character of the wild and secluded district called the Lammermuir.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: The beauty of the Lammermuir is only equalled by its loneliness ; miles occasionally intervene between the farm-steadings ; and I have fished the Whitadder from Auld Martha's to the Elmford, without meeting  an angler on the stream.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Sunday has dawned again ; and although Galium Beg declares in Waverley, that it never comes abune a Highland pass with an unpronounceable  name, I dissent from the young reprobate altogether ; and I hereby avow, that I never saw a Sabbath kept more religiously than yesterday's was in the Lammermuir.
